Steam 42 / Nuclear Waste Management
The Babcock & Wilcox Company
Completion of the nuclear fuel cycle with the safe 
disposal of spent fuel is an important element of the 
commercial nuclear power industry. The overall goal of 
an integrated nuclear waste management program is 
to immobilize and isolate the nuclear material from the 
ecosystem until it no longer poses a significant threat to 
the environment.
As discussed in Chapter 48, one option for disposal 
is to reprocess the used or spent fuel bundles to recover 
uranium and plutonium for further use and to concentrate 
the highly radioactive products of the fission process plus 
transuranium elements into a smaller volume of waste. 
The other option is to dispose of the spent fuel without 
reprocessing (referred to as the once-through cycle). In 
either case, the disposal of such high level waste (HLW) 
requires the safe, undisturbed confinement of material 
for hundreds of years. Other waste materials with lower 
levels of residual radioactivity must also be handled and 
stored appropriately.
A key factor of the proper disposal of spent fuel is the 
prevention of contact between radioactive material and 
ground water because such contact could allow for the con­
taminated material to spread easily into the environment.
The nuclear waste management system includes 
temporary on-site storage immediately after use in the 
reactor, transportation, long-term storage, processing 
into an alternate form, and ultimate long-term disposal.
At the start of the nuclear age in the 1940s through 
the 1960s, high level waste from reprocessing was stored 
in tanks for later disposal. Commercial reactor fuel, 
like defense reactor fuel, was to be reprocessed and the 
resultant small volume of waste was to be stored until a 
disposal technique was chosen.
Since the early 1970s, waste storage regulations 
have become progressively more rigorous in response 
to environmental concerns. The nuclear industry has 
responded to this trend by significantly reducing the 
amount of waste produced while ensuring safe storage 
of the remaining material.
The products classified as nuclear waste range from 
slightly contaminated disposable clothing to highly 
radioactive recyclable fuel byproducts. The methods 
used to treat and manage the different forms of waste 
vary widely.
Nuclear Waste Definitions and Descriptions 
There are four common categories of nuclear waste: 
high level, transuranic, mill tailings and low level.

Nuclear Waste Management
High level waste 
High level waste (HLW) is the byproduct of the repro­
cessing of spent nuclear reactor fuel which has undergone 
significant irradiation. HLW contains virtually all of the 
fission products and most of the transuranium elements 
produced by the fission process. (See Chapters 48 and 
49.) If spent nuclear fuel is not reprocessed, the spent 
fuel elements are also treated as HLW.
High level waste from reprocessing usually takes the 
form of a viscous liquid after concentration by evaporation. 
It is initially stored as an aqueous nitric acid solution 
in high integrity stainless steel tanks until its initially 
high activity level and resulting heat generation decline.
Typical plans call for the permanent storage of this 
waste as a solid. In one option, the viscous liquid is mixed 
with borosilicate glass, melted, and then solidified inside 
stainless steel canisters in a process called vitrification. 
This process immobilizes the radioactive material in a 
stable mass which is highly resistant to leaching of the 
radioactive material if it ever comes in contact with water. 
The solid mass is still highly radioactive and requires 
shielding and careful handling. Radiation from HLW 
declines with time, with the general radioactivity drop­
ping to a level comparable to naturally occurring uranium 
ore in less than 1000 years. In addition, the waste must 
be isolated from the biosphere for many years. HLW heat 
generation must also be handled in storage facilities. 
Certain waste resulting from the reprocessing of spent 
nuclear fuel can also be classified as waste incidental to 
reprocessing rather than HLW, with similar handling 
and storage options.
Although less radioactive than HLW, greater than 
Class C (GTCC) materials are usually considered as 
HLW. These materials have been subjected to significant 
neutron irradiation and their residual radiation levels 
are relatively high. Reactor components that contain 
significant amounts of cobalt, if subjected to an extremely 
high neutron field, generate enough gamma rays to be 
classified as GTCC. Examples include stainless steel 
core control assembly components and fuel end fittings. 
Most metals, such as the Zircaloy fuel rod cladding, can 
withstand a large radiation field without becoming a 
radiation source. GTCC waste produces little heat, but 
it must be shielded for transport or storage.
Transuranic waste 
Transuranic (TRU) refers to atoms of man-made 
elements containing isotopes with atomic weights

greater than uranium-238 (U-238). These wastes are 
the byproducts of weapons production, plutonium, or 
mixed oxide fuel production or fuel reprocessing. The 
most common element is plutonium.
Transuranic waste, by definition, has a half life 
greater than 20 years and a total activity exceeding 100 
nanocuries (nCi) per gram of material; it generates little 
heat. Before 1970, these materials were classified as low 
level wastes and were treated accordingly. TRU waste 
is now considered in three categories and each requires 
a different level of treatment and disposal. Contact-
handled TRU (CH-TRU) waste has a surface dose less 
than 200 millirem per hour (mR/h), remote-handled 
TRU (RH-TRU) waste has a surface dose greater than 
200 mR/h, and special TRU (SP-TRU) waste is a large 
contaminated piece of equipment. Nearly all TRU waste 
is the contact-handled type.
Mill tailings 
Mill tailings are the byproducts from mining and 
processing uranium ore. They contain elements such as 
thorium and radium that are byproducts of natural U-238 
decay. The tailings are generally piped to a disposal pit 
as sludge where they dry into a pile. Although there is 
no heat generation and the radiation generated by these 
piles is insignificant, the material must be stabilized 
to prevent migration into water supplies or airborne 
contamination. An additional concern is the generation 
of radon gas caused by the radium decay. This gas can 
be carried by the wind and can deposit in lung tissues in 
a harmful manner.
Low level waste 
Low level waste (LLW) is any waste with a self-
generated radiation field that does not fall into one of the 
previous categories and has less than 10 nCi per gram of 
transuranium contaminants and low concentrations of 
radioactive materials. This waste can range from reactor 
components to home fire alarms. LLW is categorized 
as Class A, B or C, or below regulatory concern (BRC), 
according to United States (U.S.) federal regulations. LLW 
can come from defense, nuclear power or industrial sources.
Defense and nuclear power low level waste is typically 
generated by one of two methods: either activation or 
fission product migration. Activation occurs when 
materials are exposed to a neutron radiation field. 
These materials may 1) remain in a large component 
such as a pressure vessel, 2) break down as corrosion 
products and be deposited on other surfaces, or 3) exist 
as surface/water impurities that migrate to other areas. 
Tritium generation from boron in reactor cooling water 
is an example of activation. Fission product migration 
can result from small quantities of radiation escaping 
from fuel rod leaks or from uranium contamination on 
the outside of the rods. Fission products can be gaseous, 
soluble in water, or solid fragments capable of water or 
air migration.
Most defense or power LLW can be grouped either as 
protective materials, bulk waste, or liquid derivatives. 
Protective materials include anti-contamination clothing 
and other sealing, cleaning and wrapping agents. Bulk 
waste encompasses dirt, concrete, metal components or 
debris. Liquid derivatives include ion exchange resins 
used for coolant purification, evaporator concentrates, 
steam generator cleaning solutions, and sludges from 
contaminated oil recovery.
Institutional wastes come from research organiza­
tions, universities, laboratories, medical facilities, 
hospitals and medical schools. They include solid wastes 
(glass, metal and plastic), biological wastes (tissue) and 
chemical wastes (scintillation detector fluids and barium).
Industrial LLWs are generated by fabricators of smoke 
detectors, pacemakers and airport lighting systems. They 
can also be byproducts of processes such as oil drilling and 
food sterilization. Pharmaceutical companies and nuclear 
fuel fabrication plants are additional sources of LLW.
Because the radiation levels in BRC materials are 
extremely low, these materials can be disposed of with no 
specific regard for their radioactivity. Class A wastes are 
more strictly regulated. They must be stored in leakproof 
noncardboard containers; liquids must be solidified or 
mixed with an absorbent. Class A wastes must contain 
no explosive or spontaneously combustible materials and 
pressure from gases must be minimal.
Class B LLW must meet all Class A requirements, but 
must also be stabilized, i.e., its container must keep its 
size and shape in the presence of moisture, emplacement 
overburden, or radiation during its disposal life. Class C 
LLW must meet Class A and Class B requirements and 
must be packaged and disposed of to prevent inadvertent 
intrusion after the disposal site is closed. This is usually 
accomplished by layering the waste, placing the Class C 
material in the bottom layers.
Mixed waste 
A waste stream that combines LLW with non-nuclear 
hazardous material is called mixed waste. Although this 
form of waste is common and regulated in Europe, it is 
prohibited in the U.S. Domestic LLW is regulated by 
the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC), whereas 
hazardous waste is controlled by the Environmental 
Protection Agency (EPA). Control of existing mixed waste 
is shared by these agencies on a case-by-case basis.
Also in the U.S., mixed waste is further divided into 
three principal types. Low level mixed waste is primarily 
the result of research and weapons production. High level 
mixed waste results from spent fuel reprocessing and ir­
radiated targets from reactors. Mixed transuranic waste 
results from weapons manufacturing, plutonium-bearing 
fuel fabrication, and spent fuel reprocessing.
Nuclear Waste Storage 
Waste storage is a prime concern in nuclear power 
generation. Early nuclear plant sites were designed to 
use closed fuel cycles. As such, storage pools for spent fuel 
were only designed to have the capacity for storing a frac­
tion of the plant’s lifetime fuel supply and the intent was 
to ship the spent fuel to a reprocessing facility to reclaim 
fuel components. The resultant waste stream would be 
small and could be stored for long-term radioactive decay 
before disposal.
Just as large reprocessing plants at Morris, Illinois, 
and Barnwell, South Carolina, were being brought on line, 
government regulations in the 1970s effectively banned 
the recycling of nuclear wastes in the U.S. Although the 
reprocessing moratorium was rescinded in the 1980s,

little commercial recycling occurred in the U.S. due to 
the large capital losses sustained in the 1970s. However, 
ongoing reprocessing programs are underway in countries 
such as France, the United Kingdom (U.K.), Russia and 
Japan.
Nuclear plants in the U.S. consequently had to 
determine other ways of handling the radioactive 
spent fuel assemblies. Options included expanding the 
capacity of existing storage pools, shipping the waste 
to an off-site storage location, and creating new on-site 
storage facilities.
Early storage pools could hold only two to three times 
the amount of fuel needed to fill the core. The large 
spacing between fuel assemblies prevented inadvertent 
criticality and their capacity would have been sufficient 
if the fuel were reprocessed. New storage pool designs 
of the late 1970s used high density racks which relied 
on neutron absorber materials rather than geometry to 
prevent criticality. As rack designs improved, utilities 
were successful in re-racking the spent fuel pools until 
maximum capacity was achieved. Storage capacity at 
Duke Energy Corporation’s Oconee Unit 3 in the U.S., for 
example, tripled with this improved technology.
Spent fuel management options 
Even with maximum re-racking, plants can only store 
a portion of the spent fuel during the total projected plant 
life. Several management options have been proposed, 
studied and applied in demonstration projects that have 
not materialized as viable solutions. These include double-
tiered pool storage, rod consolidation, transferal to another 
pool facility, and shipment overseas for reprocessing.
The double-tiered pool storage concept suggested 
stacking a second level of fuel racks within the spent 
fuel pool. This is not possible in most spent fuel pools 
due to structural limitations, fuel accessibility, and/or 
accountability concerns.
Rod consolidation is a method of dismantling the fuel 
assemblies where the rods are spaced apart, and then 
re-storing the rods within a container allowing for a 
higher compaction ratio. While this process was used at 
a few plants, it has since been abandoned due to several 
technical issues rendering the process more difficult and 
costly than anticipated.
The transfer of spent fuel to a separate wet storage 
facility has been accomplished in some cases, but the 
availability of wet storage facilities to accept fuel is 
limited. An example of a successful transfer program is 
the Shearon Harris plant in the U.S., which has a storage 
pool originally designed to service three reactors. Because 
only one reactor was completed at this location, spent fuel 
assemblies from the owner’s Robinson and Brunswick 
plants have been shipped there. However, this is not a 
typical situation and such transferal is, therefore, not a 
common option for utilities.
With respect to shipping fuel outside of the U.S. for 
reprocessing, some countries have indicated an interest 
in recycling U.S. commercial spent fuel. However, legal 
issues and high cost have precluded this option to date.
There are two parallel approaches currently being 
used to address spent fuel management in commercial 
nuclear plants. First, the fuel is being used longer during 
operation in the reactor (high burnup), and second, on-site 
dry storage facilities are being built and operated.
To decrease storage needs, a high burnup extended 
cycle fuel may be used. Early pressurized water reactor 
(PWR) fuel featured 3% uranium-235 enrichments and 
was irradiated for three one-year cycles; a burnup of 
30,000 to 35,000 MWd/tmU was attained. Recent designs 
have enrichments up to 5% and cycle times have been 
extended up to two years. Certain fuel cycle designs 
permit fuel assemblies to remain in-core for four cycles 
and the resultant burnup has increased well beyond 
45,000 MWd/tmU. The extended burnup results in less 
fuel used and less space required for storage over the life 
of the plant.
The most widely used option for interim storage is to 
place the spent fuel in dry storage casks and remove the 
fuel from inside the plant building to a location on the 
plant property. This method involves the construction 
of an on-site independent spent fuel storage installation 
(ISFSI) where the loaded dry casks reside until their 
eventual shipment away from the plant site. All U.S. 
utilities have used or are planning to use this option, 
which began in 1986. There are currently 54 licensed 
and operating ISFSI sites (with some serving multiple 
units) and 11 commercial reactor sites pursuing new 
ISFSI licenses.
The U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) committed to 
start taking spent fuel from utilities in 1998 for interim 
storage at a monitored retrievable storage (MRS) facility, 
but this activity failed to materialize by the intended 
deadline. The DOE and a federal nuclear waste negotiator 
continue to solicit volunteer sites to host one or more MRS 
facilities. When realized, the MRS facilities will accept 
shipments of spent nuclear fuel from commercial power 
plants, will store the fuel temporarily above ground, 
and will eventually deposit the shipments in a geologic 
repository for permanent disposal.
Storage container materials 
In the 1980s, the Virginia Electric Power Company 
(VEPCO), the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) 
and the U.S. DOE jointly reviewed the feasibility of 
dual purpose metal casks (long-term storage followed 
by transport to a disposal site). Although none of 
those particular designs were able to obtain licensing 
certification for transport, several were certified for 
storage. VEPCO’s Surry plant pioneered the use of these 
metal casks for storing spent nuclear material. Since 
then, several metal casks have been licensed for dual 
purpose; however, their use for storage is economically 
unfavorable. 
Currently, the most common dry storage technolo­
gies in the U.S. employ a canister system that can be 
interchangeably placed into either a storage overpack 
or a transportable cask. The spent fuel is loaded into 
the canister, which is a thin-walled steel vessel that is 
dewatered (completely dry), backfilled with an inert gas, 
and welded shut providing a containment boundary. 
The canister is transported with a transfer cask to a 
storage overpack module, which is then placed onto an 
ISFSI pad. The storage overpack is typically constructed 
of thick concrete to provide adequate shielding, and is 
ventilated to facilitate thermal cooling. When the fuel 
is ready for shipment, the canister can be removed from

the storage overpack and then placed in the transport 
cask for shipping off site. With the canister system, the 
fuel does not need to go back into the spent fuel pool to 
transfer from the storage overpack to the transport cask. 
To date, these systems are used solely for storage and 
are not considered a substitute for permanent disposal.
In Canada, Ontario Power Generation (OPG) 
contracted with Babcock & Wilcox (B&W) Canada 
and another supplier in 2009 to fabricate and supply 
dry storage containers for its CANDU®-design PWR 
generating stations. (See Chapter 47.) Each container, 
as illustrated in Fig. 1, holds approximately 460 ft3 
(13 m3) of concrete, with inner and outer steel sleeves. 
The approximately 2 ft (0.6 m) thick walls, as well as 
the concrete closure, provide radiation shielding to 
workers and the public. Each container is composed 
of a 15 t (13.6 tm) top and 50 t (45.4 tm) base. Through 
2013, approximately 200 of these containers have been 
supplied to OPG by B&W Canada.
In the U.S., B&W Canada manufactured 11 of 
Transnuclear’s NUHOMS®-24P canisters for use at the 
Oconee Nuclear Station.
As permanent disposal options continue to see 
delays, the need for long-term dry storage technologies 
has become more important. It is expected that new 
nuclear plants will be designed for operating lives of up 
to 80 years, and dry storage options will at least equal 
this time line. ISFSI facilities using the canister-based 
storage overpack modules appear to be the fuel storage 
solution for the foreseeable future.
Storage of other HLW/LLW
The U.S. DOE and its predecessor, the Atomic Energy 
Commission (AEC), have been reprocessing spent fuel 
since the mid-1940s. Byproducts from these efforts have 
been stored in tanks located at federal facilities such as 
Hanford, Washington; Idaho Falls, Idaho; Oak Ridge, 
Tennessee; and Aiken, South Carolina. A vitrification 
plant (see High level waste section) was developed, 
constructed, operated and decommissioned at the West 
Valley Demonstration Project near Buffalo, New York, 
from 1983 to 2005. The high level wastes were solidified 
into 275 stainless steel canisters. Although the canisters 
release significant thermal and radiological emissions, 
the mixtures are stable for transportation and storage. 
A vitrification plant has been operating at the Savannah 
River Site Waste Processing Facility in Aiken, South 
Carolina, since 1996. The plan for the largest vitrification 
plant in the world began construction at the Hanford site 
in 2001 and is expected to be operational in 2022.
Most transuranic wastes are stored in liquid form in 
55 gal (208 l) drums at their point of origin. Because of 
their relatively low radioactive emissions, these wastes 
are stored in a secure but not isolated manner.
Storage of low level waste varies considerably. Most 
solid waste is wrapped, placed in sealed 55 gal (208 l) 
drums, and stored in secured areas. Although liquid 
waste can initially be stored as a liquid, it must be sta­
bilized or solidified for shipment and disposal. Reduction 
of LLW has been a high priority since the early 1980s. 
Reducing this volume has been accomplished by reducing 
its creation, compacting solid waste, and incinerating 
combustible waste.
Radioactive Material Transportation 
Substantial regulations have been developed to 
safeguard the transportation of nuclear waste material. In 
the U.S., the Department of Transportation and the NRC 
share the responsibility for safe transportation. Primary 
regulations include details regarding routing, type of 
vehicle, placarding, carrier regulations, and packaging.
The packaging requirements are an evolution of 
International Atomic Energy Agency guidelines that 
were created in the early 1950s. These requirements 
have three primary goals: 1) to limit the radiation field 
from the package (adequate shielding), 2) to contain its 
radioactive contents (confinement), and 3) to prevent 
fissioning of the contents (criticality safety).
Although skilled individuals are chosen to transport 
nuclear waste, the packaging (container) must provide 
ultimate protection in the event of an accident. Packaging 
is based on whether the waste is termed normal or special. 
Normal materials are those that can be shipped as a 
solid, liquid or gas and, if exposed to the atmosphere, do 
not pose a health threat. Special waste is hazardous if 
leakage occurs. It is usually shipped in a canister that 
provides additional containment protection in the event 
of an accident.
The level of waste radioactivity determines the type 
of shipping container. Certain materials such as smoke 
detectors and luminous signs have an extremely low level 
of radioactivity. These exempted materials require no 
special packaging. Radioactive material defined as low 
specific activity (LSA), Type A or Type B is contained 
with unique packaging.
Low specific activity
Radioactivity from LSA materials is low enough 
that inhalation or ingestion of the material presents 
little health hazard. Typical LSA materials include mill 
tailings, natural uranium hexafluoride (UF6), laboratory 
medical wastes, and reactor service tooling. Ion exchange 
resins, although LSA material, must be shipped in 
Type A containers because of their susceptibility to 
environmental diffusion. LSA packaging must prevent 
a release of contents during normal transport conditions, 
but does not provide shielding. Typical LSA containers 
are wooden boxes, 55 gal (208 l) drums and special tank 
trailers.
Type A containers
Materials with greater than LSA radioactivity require 
Type A packaging which provides containment and 
minimal shielding. Type A containers must also be able 
to withstand normal shipping conditions. Most low level 
wastes, as well as institutional and industrial materials, 
are shipped in Type A containers.
Type B containers
Type B packaging requirements are the most stringent 
and cover transport of the most radioactive or fissionable 
material. Type B containers are referred to as casks 
and, in addition to meeting Type A requirements, must 
withstand severe accident conditions without a breach 
of the container envelope. They provide containment, 
shielding and criticality protection under all conditions.

Fig. 1 illustrates a cask supplied by The Babcock & Wilcox 
Company (B&W), which is used for on-site storage of 
CANDU reactor spent fuel. Type B casks are extremely 
robust vessels and few manufacturers are certified to 
build them.
Many thousands of commercial spent fuel shipments 
in Type B casks have successfully occurred in the U.S. 
since the early 1960s. Similar records of shipment and 
safety also exist in Europe.
Most existing American spent fuel casks were 
designed to ship short-cooled fuel (fuel removed from the 
reactor and stored on location for at least six months). 
Newer casks are being designed to ship longer-cooled 
fuel to federal storage and disposal facilities. Because 
longer-cooled fuel has lower inherent thermal load and 
radiological source strength, the new casks can have 
larger payload capacities for a given overall size than 
casks for short-cooled fuel.
A special Type B package has also been designed to 
transport transuranic material. The package is known 
as a transuranic package transporter (TRUPACT). Each 
TRUPACT container holds fourteen 55 gal (208 l) drums. 
This container transporter system has been further 
improved through various TRUPACT models.
Nuclear Waste Disposal Systems 
Concern for the environmental impact of nuclear waste 
has promoted stringent disposal legislation. In addition, 
the siting, licensing and operation of waste disposal 
facilities have received increased attention.
High level waste 
In the U.S., the Nuclear Waste Policy Act (NWPA) of 
1982 provided guidelines for disposing industrial spent 
fuel and defense high level radioactive wastes. Although 
separate sites were evaluated, in 1987 the federal govern­
ment decided both types of waste were to be stored in the 
same repositories.
A number of disposal options were considered for 
long-term storage of the waste including geological 
repositories, an underwater fault line in the sea, under 
the Antarctic ice, and launching the material into space 
toward the sun. Geological disposal in an isolated medium 
was chosen as the best method to prevent subsequent 
nuclide migration in the biosphere. To verify this choice, 
spent fuel assemblies were placed into vertical boreholes 
at the Climax Mine in Nevada. The conditions of the 
fuel and rock were studied for several years and the test 
results confirmed that this type of repository was safe 
and practical.
Also in the 1980s, the EPA and NRC established the 
following repository standards in addition to those placed 
on operating nuclear facilities:
1.	 Any stored spent fuel or high level waste must be 
recoverable for 50 years after closure of the repository.
2.	 The waste packages must be leak proof for a minimum 
of 300 to 1000 years.
3.	 Only phased releases of specific nuclides would be 
permitted for the subsequent 9000 years.
The man-made waste package, packing, liners and 
seals are referred to as the repository engineered barrier 
system; the geological medium and its characteristics are 
termed the repository natural barrier system.
In response to the 1982 NWPA, the U.S. DOE 
established the Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste 
Management (OCRWM) and a federal nuclear waste 
management system. Responsibilities include HLW 
disposal and repository site search, interim storage and 
its siting, and the transportation system required to 
support those sites. The transportation responsibilities 
include development of shipping casks and the creation 
of an appropriate infrastructure. Emergency response 
teams, satellite tracking systems and maintenance 
facilities, which are important public interfaces, are also 
part of this network.
The greatest challenge is establishing the media for, 
and locations of, geological repositories. Several geological 
media are candidates— rock salt, granite, clay, basalt (a 
glass-like volcanic rock) and tuff (a compacted volcanic 
rock). All of these materials exist in large continuous 
deposits. Site acceptability criteria include proximity 
to national parks or population centers, the value of 
minerals that cannot be recovered in the repository area, 
and the probability of nuclide migrations. After extensive 
characterization studies and, at times, strong debate, 
Yucca Mountain in Nevada was selected for investigation 
as the initial nuclear waste repository site by the Nuclear 
Waste Amendments Act of 1987. Tunneling operations 
for site assessment began in 1994.
In 2002, the U.S. Secretary of Energy recommended 
the Yucca Mountain site to the U.S. president, who agreed 
and notified Congress of the decision. However, the 
Governor of Nevada vetoed the move, and it was returned 
to Congress. Both Houses of Congress approved moving 
forward, and the Yucca Mountain Siting Resolution 
was signed into U.S. law on July 23, 2002, officially 
designating Yucca Mountain as the nation’s nuclear 
waste repository site.
The following year, as the U.S. DOE continued its 
mandatory license application to the NRC, the project 
was labeled as over budget and behind schedule. By 
2004, the targeted 2010 opening was in doubt. By 2008, 
project milestones were being reassessed, due primarily 
to budget shortfalls and restrictions. Project budgets 
were further reduced in 2009. In 2011, the U.S. president 
announced an end to government funding. The NRC’s 
licensing review was therefore suspended.
That same Federal Administration established the 
Blue Ribbon Commission on America’s Nuclear Future 
to review nuclear waste policies and issues, and to 
recommend a new strategy. The Commission’s final 
report was issued in January 2012. Recommendations 
included a new facility siting process, authorization of 
consolidated interim storage facilities, and establishment 
of a new waste management organization. The search for 
long-term solutions in the U.S. continues.
Transuranic waste 
The U.S. government has also committed to dispose 
of TRU in a geological repository. In 1957 the National 
Academy of Sciences recommended investigating salt 
as a disposal medium. Rock salt, in bedded or domed 
form, has several advantages. It is inexpensive, easy to 
excavate, is nearly impermeable, and its deposits are

in inherently dry areas. Development of a long-term 
disposal site in the U.S. began with testing of a Waste 
Isolation Pilot Plant (WIPP) in 1992 near Carlsbad, 
New Mexico. Key issues included migration of the TRU 
waste, metal deterioration and nuclide release. In 1999 
this pilot plant became the nation’s first repository for 
the permanent disposal of defense-generated radioactive 
waste from the development and production of nuclear 
weapons. The facility began receiving shipments in 2007, 
and through 2013, the WIPP has received approximately 
12,000 shipments containing over 3.1 × 106 ft3 (89,000 
m3) of transuranic waste.
Low level waste 
Low level waste was originally disposed of by the 
AEC at government sites using near-surface burial. 
In 1963, the first commercial LLW disposal site was 
opened. By 1971, there were six U.S. sites operating: 
Barnwell, South Carolina; Beatty, Nevada; Maxey Flat, 
Kentucky; Richland, Washington; Sheffield, Illinois; and 
West Valley, New York. These sites also featured shallow 
land burial and the facilities met the federal regulations 
at that time.
Shallow land burial was performed by locating reason­
ably dry soil, digging a 15 ft (4.6 m) deep trench, filling 
it with as-received boxes and drums to nearly ground 
level, and covering the trench with a 5 ft (1.5 m) thick 
compacted earthen cap. Ground water monitoring sumps 
were occasionally used and off-site wells were monitored 
for nuclide migration. However, these unsophisticated 
disposal methods were rarely successful. Some sites de­
veloped leaks and were closed while others have remained 
open. The active sites now feature improved techniques.
In response to these early disposal problems, additional 
government regulations were enacted. These regulations 
permit sites to operate for about 30 years. The sites are 
then closed and monitored and controlled for the next 100 
years. Off-site effluents are prohibited for an additional 
400 years. In 1980, the Low Level Radioactive Waste 
Policy Act was passed placing responsibility for LLW 
disposal on generator states and recommended regional 
facilities. In 1985, this act also required the Barnwell, 
Beatty and Richland sites to remain open through 1992. 
As of March 2012, three sites remained licensed in 
the U.S., in the states of Washington, Utah and South 
Carolina, and an additional site was opened in Texas.
Several new techniques that make LLW disposal safer 
for workers and the public have been developed. Packaging 
designs now eliminate voids when stacking materials. All 
contents are compacted or stabilized, thereby eliminating 
liquids. As a result, the total volume of disposed low level 
wastes per year was cut in half from 2005 through 2011. 
In addition, all corrosive materials are stored in advanced 
material containers and all containers must meet federal 
standards. Disposal sites have also been improved. Both 
above-ground and below-ground vaults are now used.
